work.p: The first two lines in this manuscript are similar to the following lines in the first poem in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, which was later titled "Song of Myself": "Shall I pray? Shall I venerate and be ceremonious? / I have pried through the strata and analyzed to a hair" (1855, pp. 25–6).

titleStmt.title: I shall venerate hours and
a machine readable transcription

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Whitman likely drafted this manuscript between 1850 and 1855, as he was composing the first (1855) edition of Leaves of Grass. Some of the language in the manuscript is similar to language in the first poem of that edition, eventually titled "Song of Myself."

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: I shall venerate hours and
bibl.orgName: The Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature, New York Public Library
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
On the back of this manuscript is another poetry draft.

revisionDesc.change: checked and corrected file, added corresps

lg.l:
I shall venerate hours and days, and think
them immeasurable infinite stupendous hereafter;

I am finding how much I am passing can pass through
in a few minutes.—
I was a good friend to all things before,

But now what I was seems to me limpsy
and little.
